title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Ethiopia before 1 January 2017?
preds: A reasonable interpretation of the available data indicates the criteria has been met.
Down 5% to be closer to the consensus.
Adjusting down for the passage of time.

ACLED data shows rolling 12 month total from 11/12/15- 11/12-16 of 1,029 civilians killed by security forces for events coded violence against civilians only (here I am excluding riots/protests, which I have previously included, and still believe should count) in Oromia, Addis Ababa, and Amhara. These are civilians deliberately targeted and killed by security forces because of a specific ethinic and political identity (non-Tigrayan ethnicity and anti-TPLF political identity).
Reducing from the 45% entered on 10 Oct in the absence of further news.

Some debate as to fatality numbers but most human rights groups suggest around 500 over the past year. An accurate count is impossible, and though I suspect real numbers may be higher it's likely that EWP will err on the side of caution.
Still plenty of time for a big blow-up but Government is taking steps to placate observers in and out of the troubled nation. Western media reports:
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37910542
http://www.newsweek.com/can-ethiopias-new-cabinet-address-oromo-protests-518375
Down 10% on these cosmetics.

ACLED Data released today puts Violence Against Civilians (Event_Type) in Oromia (Admin 1) during 2016 (Year) at 1155. This crosses the threshold of the definition being used. My model factors in time and confidence bands. This number makes time no longer a factor since the threshold is crossed. It also is well above where a variation in the calculation. Assuming that this will continue to tick up, and despite an understanding that there are issues with reporting and the number overall (as well as general definitional ambiguity), I am sticking with the model I have been using over the past months and adjusting to 100% since it is over 1000 deaths in the time frame allocated.

If you take ACLED fatality numbers for past 12 months, for oromia (plus Addis) and amhara, and only protests and violence against civilians where security forces were involved, it's already over 1,100. Not sure how admin will score is the only reason I'm not betting higher.
If you take ACLED numbers for fatalities in incidents of violence against civilians and protests where security forces were involved, only for oromia (including Addis) and amhara

The official number of Oromo civilian deaths on ACLED is 765 (as of Oct. 29). Some issues with this number, and as I have mentioned before, definitional issues related to what is going to be counted. ACLED is probably the most accurate number publically available though, and so using that as a baseline, with only a tick up of 6 fatalities recorded since Oct 22, and the passage of time, I am going from 10% to 9%.

I think this is now 50/50.  If you look at ACLED, from Nov 1, 2015 - Oct 22, 2016 there are almost 900 fatalities from violence against civilians/protests in which security forces are coded as the perpetrators, all in greater Oromia and Amhara (so excluding conflict not related to the recent crisis in Oromia and Amhara).  ACLED has almost 380 civilians killed by security forces in Oromia and Amhara in the first 22 days of October alone.  If Nov and Dec are each 1/3 are violent as October, the 12 month total at the end of 2016 will be over 1,000.

Based on the model that I am using, which factors in the current pace of fatalities over the year and projects that out the probability of reaching 1000 fatalities (using ACLED data) against the Oromo, I have lowered my forecast from 21%. I take ACLED data looking at "violence Against Civilians" and "Oromia", which currently is at 759 fatalities. At this rate, by Jan. 1, 2017 there will be an additional 167 deaths (averaging at 23.538 fatalities per day). There would have to be a 43% increase above the 167 additional projected deaths. Using a 50% increase or decrease over this projected deaths number for probability, this puts a 93% chance that the number will stay under 1000 and a 7% chance that it will go over.

ACLED data update released.  Note for items added on October 11: "Reports of up to 380 Oromo people killed by security forces and up to 35,000 arrested across Oromia between 3-17 October in response to the riots that followed the heavy casualties during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu early October. 200 were reportedly killed in West Arsi (28 deaths already coded on 10 October), 75 in East Shewa and 47 in East Arsi (11 deaths already coded on 13 October)." From slicing and dicing the data, I *think* there have been 817 deaths in last 12 months in events that were violence against civilians and associated with the Oromo ethnic group.  These were overwhelmingly due to Ethiopian military or police forces.  An additional 151 deaths in riots/protests associated with Oromo - not all deaths of Oromo.   Basically, the large number of arrests is worrisome and the reason I've gone over 50%.  Also, not sure of current state and whether violence and protests are subsiding or not.
Just now the gummint seem to be in arresting mode rather than gunning-down mode.  Stay tuned, though: It may not work for them.

My model takes two factors, ACLED Data on "Violence Against Civilians" in Oromia, and time. In 286 days so far in 2016, the average fatalities/day is 2.5874. This projects out to 204 more deaths this year. The ACLED Data has 740 fatalities this year within the constraints outlined. This is projecting 944 fatalities. Slightly under the 1,000 fatalities needed by definition to be mass killing. Using this as the mid-point, I project 50% increased and decrease in the rate of killing per day. It would have to be an increase of 30% more deaths per day to see the threshold of 1000 crossed. If it took 40% increase then there would be a 10% probability. 50% increase would be 0%.

My model takes two factors, ACLED Data on "Violence Against Civilians" in Oromia, and time. In 286 days so far in 2016, the average fatalities/day is 2.5874. This projects out to 204 more deaths this year. The ACLED Data has 740 fatalities this year within the constraints outlined. This is projecting 944 fatalities. Slightly under the 1,000 fatalities needed by definition to be mass killing. Using this as the mid-point, I project 50% increased and decrease in the rate of killing per day. It would have to be an increase of 30% more deaths per day to see the threshold of 1000 crossed. If it took 40% increase then there would be a 10% probability. 50% increase would be 0%.

"Ethiopia faces its Tiananmen Square moment": https://www.ft.com/content/753f033c-8f9e-11e6-8df8-d3778b55a923
Also this: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/oct/12/ethiopia-state-of-emergency-protests-corruption
A valued friend of the West, but this is a country in decline - things will get much worse before they get better. Raising 10%.
The protest are growing in number. The Government has admitted to at least 500 deaths so far. Protesters claim the nuumber of deaths is twice that number

ACLED entry for the stampede on Oct 2 is for 55 deaths, coded under Riots/Protests.  Death toll probably higher but will be difficult to determine.  This article by HRW is good though: https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/10/08/qa-recent-events-and-deaths-irreecha-festival-ethiopia For the 10/8 ACLED data, filtered for Oromo ethnic group civilian fatalities, the total is just under 500 as of 10/8.  Could argue that the Amhara deaths (41) and the Oct2 deaths under riots/protests (55) should be included.

"Ethiopian security forces have killed more than 500 people during protests over the course of the last year."  https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/10/08/ethiopia-independent-inquiry-needed-irreecha comment:  per HRW & Amnesty International it seems more than 500 and assumably less that 600 have been killed in the last year.   will the new state of emergency make matters worse?

Reducing from the 75% I entered on 02 Oct after reading report that "at least 300" people had been killed. The government has officially acknowledged about 55, however.  There are less than three months left, so I expect to reduce my forecast further. However, what's interesting is that the two major ethnic groups (Oroma comprising 34% and Amhara 27%) seem to be uniting against the ruling Tigrayans (6%). The Amhara traditionally supplied the ruling class, from Emperors to the last dictator Mengistu so must also be resentful. The present government has had solid support from the US till now, but could overplay its hand with excessive violence against protesters.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36940906
Up 10%, The fundamentals (protests) are changing things, but more importantly with more press coverage comes more chance that various acts may be reported.

estimates of # of deaths in last weekend's stampede range from 52 to almost 700. Human rights group's estimates are mid-range.  http://africanarguments.org/2016/10/07/ethiopia-how-popular-uprising-became-the-only-option/ Not sure how those will be categorized by ACLED, HRW or AI, but as far as I can tell they seem to be part of the same on-going crackdown on anti-government protest movements.  Still have a few months to go before the end of the year, and seems possible to me that the two things 
(a: HRW or AI or other authoritative source will publish a report within that timeframe) 
& (b:  that the number of deaths documented will exceed 1000) 
will occur, but far from certain.

Lowering due to conversation with EWP.  A few points here though. HRW and Amnesty were indicating 400 deaths November through May as a result of the protests against the government.  Since that time, have had an additional 400 or so deaths in violence against civilians (per ACLED).  If HRW or Amnesty publishes a report prior to the end of the year which indicates a mass killing with >1000 fatalities, then appears that will be taken as closing this question.  Violence has continued, so not feeling comfortable with a very low forecast here.  Need to look at this again next week.  For what it is worth - some of the ways I've looked at the data are here: https://morrellk.wordpress.com/2016/10/06/ethiopia-acled-data/

Reverting to a much lower estimate based on the comment of the @EarlyWarningProject here: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/341587 As of now, EWP seems to assume that Oromo and Amhara protesters are two distinct groups as per their definition. EWP also seems to be quite conservative in their estimations, with reports from orgs like Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International having a large influence (and in my experience these are quite conservative due to their high standards of research). I would revert to a higher forecast should EWP decide to view Oromo and Amhara protesters as the same group (pro democracy protesters?) for the purpose of this question, or if the latest escalation (see reports on stampede and aftermath) leads to a significant uptick in protest activity and corresponding violence.

Pushing up by 5% on news of the stampede that killed at least 50 (but maybe as many as several hundred) Oromo after police fired tear gas and rubber bullets into a crowd: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37534387 Not sure how many (if any) of the dead will be counted under the EWP definition, but this event also increases the likelihood of future protest and corresponding state violence.

Moving my forecast up from 25% to 35% based on a number of reports of casualties. Additionally, it appears clear that there has been an escalation recently. Reports have been "fuzzy" as to what the level of fatalities are, which keeps the probability below 50%. That said, ACLED has over 500 reported deaths in less than a years period for the Oromo region.

maintaining 0%.  If the Early Warning Project aligned it's language and definitions of victims along the same lines as the U.S. Military definition of victims would EWP have a greater impact/meaning?  The U.S. Military will probably be the agency to do something about it.  Having an understanding of U.S. Military Joint Doctrine on Mass Atrocity Response Operations may help write better questions. (apology for multiple edits :)  JP3-07-3 page B-5 discusses victim groups.
https://fas.org/blogs/secrecy/2013/06/dod-maro/
http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/new_pubs/jointpub_operations.htm

Pushing back up to 33% on reports of dozens of Oromo protesters killed during anti-government protests at a religious festival this weekend: http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/96e9600c-88b1-11e6-8cb7-e7ada1d123b1.html

Reports, as noted by @Khalid, of stampede & deaths.  Bit confused as to how many at this time & I don't know if they will be counted as civilians (unarmed) or not. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37534387.   Worth noting that some of the deaths that have occurred in Ethiopia in the last year are almost certainly a different episode than the state-related violence seen the last two months.  A South Sudanese militia (Murle Ethnic militia) killed 208 civilians in April.  Still - August and September have been much more violent than earlier this year and does not appear to be abating.

I've been low on this question since it started, but news is just coming out of at least 300 Oromia killed, mostly in a stampede after government forces opened fire (sorry, no link at this time but it's on BBC). This follows reports of 400 killed in August. Counting the deaths late last year, that makes more than 1000 in under 12 months, all of the same ethnic group against the government. EPW may decide that many of these fatalities weren't deliberately targeted, and just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. However, I think it's worth increasing the probability from almost certainly not to likely. Matters could get worse from now on.
It's coming - just not yet. Expecting to see this question rejigged for 2017.

I've updated the data provided by ACLED in my spreadsheet and corresponding graph: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Q3H4a9zjsu1EsE8exb-6innpIhBZZU2oMjHgY6aRMig/edit?usp=sharing Some key observations:
- ACLED seems to do a considerable amount of "backloading", as in adding database entries weeks and months after the events. While the data reported 585 fatalities in its "violence against civilians" category for the 12 months running up to August 26, it now reports 688 fatalities for the same time period. This is likely due to the way ACLED handles its input data (and the delayed availability of that data) and I will anticipate this behavior in future analyses.
- As of today, 804 people have been killed in the last 12 months in "violence against civilians" events, already more than my initial estimate. I will assume that the actual number is even higher because of ACLED "backloading"
-  The patterns of violence that I talked about in my last comment (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/311161) seem to have changed. While killings were concentrated around individual large scale protest events for the better part of the year, since the last wave of protests civilians have continued to suffer at a pretty consistent pace. The last 30 days saw 120 civilian deaths, dispersed over several distinct events, pointing to an escalation of the violence perpetrated by government forces.
- Perhaps the reason for the escalating violence, protest events seem to spread across more (and smaller) towns within the country.  Based on this new data, I am pretty certain that ACLED will see more than 1,000 deaths at the end of the year. The challenge is of course that the question doesn't ask for a forecast on ACLED data, but is based on the EWP's definition of "mass killing", which has additional requirements pertaining to the nature of the victims. It would be great to have a representative of the EWP comment on how they see the current situation in Ethiopia and if all or the majority of the civilian deaths so far fit into their definition or not. Until then, this question presents the most important source of uncertainty, not actual developments on the ground. I will nonetheless increase my forecast considerably. At this time I assume that about 750 people have been killed since January 1 under circumstances consistent with EWP's definition. Given that the Ethiopian government has so far not reacted in any material way to the protesters' demands and grievances, I will assume that current levels of violence will at least continue, if not become worse. This puts my revised estimate at 60%. I will change this estimate based on future ACLED data, as well as any information of how EWP interprets the current situation.

I think the probability here is too low.  According to ACLED, 744 civilians have been killed (as of September 24).  Assuming 3.4 per day for the rest of September, or 21 total, that's an estimated 765 for Jan - Sep.  That's 85 a month in 2016.  If this rate holds for the next three months, the total would be around 1020.   The killing has of course not been uniformly distributed, with significant spikes in February (100), April (233), and August (256).  Without another spike, totals likely won't top 1000.  However, a similar spike in the next three months could very well occur, and the trajectory of violence in Ethiopia continues to point upwards. Understanding that not all of these killings have targeted Oromo (maybe 80% have), not sure this would meet the definitions criteria.  Assuming that 80% do meet the criteria however, the probability should be far higher than 5% - somewhere in the 20 to 50% range.
increase in deaths recorded in ACLED database recently (Aug/Sept).  Many of those are protesters & rioters - not entirely sure about the counting for EWP.

Fatalities for September 1-3 were alarming: 54 deaths by military: 7 civilians, 25 protesters, 22 rioters and 2 civilian deaths by prison guards.  That's a lot for 3 days, and there was a big jump in civilian fatalities in the latter part of August.
Given that killings have to be specifically targeted, reducing probability.

Based on ACLED data (collected here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Q3H4a9zjsu1EsE8exb-6innpIhBZZU2oMjHgY6aRMig/edit?usp=sharing) Ethiopia experienced 585 fatalities in "violence against civilians" over the last 12 months (note that ACLED's definition doesn't necessarily reflect the EWP's calculation of civilian fatalities). Practically all of these fatalities occured after 31 December 2015, so they won't "expire" before the question runs out. Projecting the current rate would leave fatalities short of 1,000, but not considerably. Assuming current levels of violence, I estimate that 2016 will see around 800 total civilian deaths at the hands of security forces. Note that this report by Amnesty International (https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/08/ethiopia-dozens-killed-as-police-use-excessive-force-against-peaceful-protesters/) seems to be already reflected in the data. Looking at the patterns of violence against civilians reflected in the ACLED data, it seems like the vast majority of killings happen in the wake of mass protests that are suppressed violently by security forces. Since the beginning of 2016 I count three of these extremely violent episodes, with fatalities reaching from about 100 to more than 200 for each of them. I make the assumption that the basic dynamic of this violence won't change (e.g. the Ethiopian government won't start going from door to door killing opposition members, but will continue to meet any form of protest with extreme violence). We should expect one or two more weekends of mass demonstrations which will result in an average of 150 civilian fatalities if the trend holds, leaving the total well below the 1,000 mark. That would put the probability of the question resolving with "yes" at well below 50%, I would argue at about 10%. There are reports (http://qz.com/757824/how-the-ethiopia-protests-were-stifled-by-a-coordinated-internet-shutdown/) that the Ethiopian government has for the first time shut down online access during the last protests. Assuming these tactics are continued and handled professionally, it would reduce the capacity of protesters to organize, thus limit protests and fatalities. On this assumption I subtract 5% off my forecast. But the geographic reach of the protests are spreading, with some of the most significant demonstrations of the last wake taking place in Amhara region. This puts the ruling elite under considerable pressure (http://www.africa-confidential.com/article/id/11754/The_centre_holds_on) and increases the potential for large-scale demonstrations and corresponding violence, which inclines me to add 10% to my initial forecast, bringing the final tally to 15%. What I will be looking for in the future:
* Will the current dynamics of violence hold?
* How many large-scale demonstrations are we seeing/anticipating?
* Are other sections of society joining the protesters?
* The capital itself didn't see large demonstrations or much bloodshed so far. It is the largest city of the country and if it experiences a sizable demonstration with corresponding violence, it will likely push the number of fatalities up considerably.

Up on Shiva's link. However 400 deaths to date doesn't support a total of 1 000 deaths, which is a high threshold. "State security forces in Ethiopia have used excessive and lethal force against largely 
peaceful protests that have  swept through Oromia, the country’s largest region, since 
November 2015. Over 400 people are estimated to have been killed"
https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/report_pdf/ethiopia0616web.pdf

August 11, 2016 (ADDIS ABABA) – Continued Anti-government protests in Ethiopia’s Oromiya and Amhara regions are claiming more lives. Sources reveled that at least 100 people including members of the security forces have been killed since the weekend after the protests turned violent leading to clashs.
http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article59896 Still a long way short of the magic 1 000 number, and unlikely to get there this year.

https://www.buzzfeed.com/claudiakoerner/an-ethiopian-runner-protested-at-the-olympics-in-spite-of-fe?utm_term=.kc07pED15#.oiemeGQp3 "Lilesa, 26, told Sports Illustrated that more than a thousand Oromo people have been killed in Ethiopia in the last nine months. "

Moving my forecast upwards on the basis of the recent reports. Unclear what the levels are and I am suspicious of the 100 person number for two reasons. First, 100 civilian fatalities in that type of opening fire by police is high (but not totally unprecedented. Second, the possibility that the number is trending higher in order to bring international pressure to allow for an investigation. Still, it is evident that there was a high fatality rate, adding on to an already very high fatality rate (as reported by ACLED realtime data set), specifically in Oromia and against the Oromo Ethnic Group.

Up another 4% as there's a chance this question could be resolved over the course of a lazy afternoon. All it may take is a major protest gathering (likely) to get out of hand (also likely). 
Thousands of Oromo and Amhara protesters remain in custody, and grievances against the Tigray elites are likely to gather steam. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jb2XxImw24c

I am upping my prediction in part from a 1:3 an almost 1:2 
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36940906

I'm doubling my forecast, from 10 to 20 percent, on a new Amnesty International report that Ethiopian security forces killed nearly 100 people in the past week during protests in Oromia and Amhara: https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/08/ethiopia-dozens-killed-as-police-use-excessive-force-against-peaceful-protesters/ This is a continuation of a process that started last year, and the cumulative total is now in the several hundreds. If the question structure allowed for the accumulation of fatalities across calendar years, I would push my forecast much higher. As I understand the resolution criteria, though, we have to consider only fatalities from the current calendar year. So, I'm still closer to 0 than 0.5 or 1.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/global-opinions/ethiopias-regime-has-killed-hundreds-why-is-the-west-still-giving-it-aid/2016/08/09/3adc4dac-5e58-11e6-9d2f-b1a3564181a1_story.html Almost 100 protesters - mainly Oromo - killed by government "security forces" in the past few days. More to come?

EWP: "We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less." The "qualifying" death toll this year might be in the hundreds already. See: http://allafrica.com/stories/201608081276.html Obtaining solid statistics will be difficult, so closing this question in the affirmative would likely require a particularly severe atrocity, sufficient to be widely reported in the international press. It looks like the Ethiopian government has pretty good control on how news gets out though, which may make it difficult to ever determine precise body counts. I'm actually surprised at how low on the global radar this country is, given the ongoing nature of events like that listed in the article above.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ethiopia-violence-idUSKCN10J0Z8?il=0
Well, you can't say they're not trying.  Still a ways to go, but diligence may yet pay off.  Moving up some.
Based on Crisis Watch data, fatalities are low leve and segmented into several conflicts with several groups in different areas of Ethiopia.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.
Down 3% to be closer to consensus.

(no change) First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode starts on 2 February 2016 and ends 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to weigh in to explain the unexplainable.)

(no change) Here is one link I've relied on to confirm that the EWP questions are for the full calendar year 2016: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244986 I interpret this as confirming that it is for a full calendar year (if not otherwise specified).
Ethiopia far less volatile than neighbours
Down 5% on passage of time and to be closer to consensus.

The new report from Human Rights Watch puts Ethiopia pretty far along the path toward a state-led mass killing targeting Oromos. Nevertheless, I am only pushing my forecast up to 8% for now because it appears that the intense repression has succeeded (ugh) in quashing the movement for now. That's unusual, actually. Most of the time, these situations either stay at relatively low levels, with tens or maybe scores killed,  or they escalate fairly rapidly to much higher counts that cross the 1,000-death threshold. This case may turn out to be one of the unusual exceptions.

US Human Rights Watch put Oromo deaths at 400 since November 2015.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36546917 Full HRW report:
https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/report_pdf/ethiopia0616web.pdf
Detailed list of victims covers Dec 1, 2015 through early May 2016, numbers tend to fall off in April and May.  Given the descriptions in the report, not certain that the full extent of the violence has been documented.

Doesn't look as though there will be an escalation of government-Oromo hostilities. Interesting to watch developments around Eritrean border, but that aside it looks like Ethiopia will just have its usual number of disappearances and extra-judicial executions.
(no change) Wonder if there may be factors related to the Blue Nile dam construction: http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article59119

Forecast probably doesn't match the reality, but accurate reporting of extrajudicial killings is notoriously hard to come by. Will keep a close watch on developing tensions between Oromo and Ethiopian government.
Down from 6% last month, on lack of relevant news and passage of time
(no change) Surprised there have been no links or discussion regarding famine in Ethiopia.
No news of violent internal conflicts that could precipitate it currently.

http://www.ayyaantuu.net/rubio-colleagues-condemn-ethiopias-crackdown-on-civil-society/
I'm hoping more pressure will lead to more reporting.

Surrounded by Sudan, South Sudan, Eritrea and Somalia.
Add to it, internal dissidents. Government actions on them in a piecemeal.
It's coming.

Lowered in discussion with Jay. I need to provide better evidence / reports (even if anecdotal), but I am of the opinion that if there were 140-270 between Nov and Jan, then with the increasing crackdowns and aggression of the State, and increased arrestees and disappeared, 1,000 dead is a likely scenario by 1 Jan.
http://www.ayyaantuu.net/ethiopia-the-tplf-hidden-agenda-of-reducing-the-oromo-population-must-be-stopped/

Some useful details on the recent killings in the area near the South Sudan border and the conflict that preceded it and persists: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/26/world/africa/ethiopia-south-sudan-nuer-highlander.html This piece reports 208 Nuer dead in those attacks by Murle raiders and perhaps as many as 15 dead in clashes between Nuer and Ethiopian "highlanders" in recent weeks. I don't think either of these conflict pairs is likely to escalate all the way to the level required for an EWP "mass killing" episode, so I am not changing my forecast. The closer one is the Murle-Nuer conflict, obviously, but these communal conflicts usually come in bursts like the one that already happened; they don't often escalate into sustained, intense fighting that can produce as many as 1,000 noncombatant deaths in a matter of months.

I believe this has probably already happened. It is just the reporting side of the question that is the issue. I'm optimistic that some kind of accepted source will report on the issue - but it will be difficult.

EPW's Expert Opinion Pool has been at 5% since 15 January. However, things appear to be happening under the world's radar. Moving up from 5%. "JUBA (HAN) April 21, 2016. Public Diplomacy & Regional Security News.South Sudanese government on Wednesday said they agreed to launch a joint military offensive to dislodge and bring to justice ethnic Murle militia fighters who crossed into Ethiopia last Friday and massacred over 200 civilians of the ethnic Nuer community who are citizens of the neighbouring Ethiopia."
http://geeskaafrika.com/2016/04/21/s-sudan-ethiopia-launch-joint-military-operation-murle-fighters/
connected to russia out of options in syria
Ethiopia has been going nuts the past couple weeks.

Slight downgrade due to time left in the year.   I would have downgraded more, but there was news of combatants coming over from S. Sudan recently and killing 140 civilians.  This was not encorporating S. Sudan into the forecast, but it sounds like drought is a driver of the violence.   I am concerned about Oromia. The statistical risk for genocide or mass killings in Ethiopia has increased from 2.1% (2014) to 3.0% (2015).  Assuming a similar rate of increase, it is clear that the overall risk of mass killing of civilians by government is not significantly large; however, Ethiopia is considered one the most conflict prone states in the world with more recent relative stabilization.  It was ranked 12/162 in 2015.

Ethiopia is considered to be the 8th country with a rank of 7.6 out of 10 among all countries that have experienced terror endogenously (.i., domestcally).  This rank does not account for the terror originating from Ethiopia but merely terror on the country.   Regarding the impact of terror,  the country has a ranking of 50 out of 124 with a scaled value of 3.54 / 10.0 .  Al Shabaab has been primarily responsible for these deaths along with domestic and international externalities with 1,021 deaths for 2014.  With the number of attacks increasing by one and a half times to nearly 500. If this rate increases exponentially (given that terror networks always seek new and better targets with none or little counter terror activity planned or executed by the ruling government.  If the rate of attacks continue on par with 2015, we can expect it to surpass the empirical requirement of 1000 deaths in 1 year, cummulatively.  With attacks in shopping malls in Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States, including in February 2015. Although al-Shabaab has attracted members from the United Kingdom and the United States, they have not conducted attacks in countries outside of East Africa, externalities continue to arise with every successful terror operation. Private citizens are the target of 36 per cent of attacks, with an average of 2.5 deaths per attack. The military is also a major target of al-Shabaab, accounting for 237 deaths over 55 attacks. The biggest attack by al-Shabaab was against the paramilitary group Raskamboni Movement and the military forces of
Jubaland which killed 91 people. Al-Shabaab also had 70 separate kidnapping or hostage attacks which resulted in 238 deaths.   The share of world refugee population by country of refuge in 2014 was 5% of the global total.   This measure is a good indicator of the the relative extent, intensity of political instability.   Political instability in this case is not intended to exclude economic, infrastructural or military fractionalization.  All these factors provide non causal by interconnected event outcomes that leads us to potentially 'see' the movement to the mass killing ceiling. Additional note:  The intensity of terror and the rebellion in Ethiopia, like other states, indicates where the state will place its resources,  Since rebel and terror movement hide members of their cells among urban centers and rural populations, this also provides and indication of what counter-terror directions a state would take.   An additional indicator, particularly in Africa is the degree of social cohesion in societies that are heavily fragmented along lines of ethnicity (ie., ethnic backgrounds and affiliation).    It is in this social space where governments, severely fragmented along ethnic lines, commit mass killings along with other acts of terror, such as genocides.

Ethiopia is experiencing the worst drought in fifty years. Resource scarcity breeds political tensions. CFR: "As of February 2016, 75 percent of harvests have been lost, one million livestock have died, and ten to fifteen million people require emergency humanitarian food assistance, with 430,000 children experiencing severe malnutrition."

The mass-killing questions are a great, if depressing, addition to this exercise.  Very few people (one hopes) are in favour of mass killings; so even more than other Qs, these ones may impel us to examine scrupulously the differences among what we hope will happen, what we think ought to happen, and what we expect will happen.   As an academic, I hate being impelled to think, especially about the possibility that I may be wrong.  However, my wife and daughter assure me that it's good for me some goddam way, and they are both miles smarter than I. That said, I do wish everyone in the countries with mass-killing Qs a long and happy life.

Misread the definition of mass killing which constitutes the death of at least 1000 people, which are less likely than type of killings with smaller numbers that I researched. So I'm updating for now to a much lower probability until I can do more research.

I found claims of 6 mass killings in the four years from 2012-2015 (including a failed terrorist plot 2013 in which Somali terrorists accidentally blew themselves up).
1 November 2015, https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/12/18/ethiopia-lethal-force-against-protesters
2&3	April and May 2014, http://www.nation.co.ke/news/africa/Five-killed-in-Ethiopia-over-land-demonstrations/-/1066/2998006/-/yhfojez/-/index.html
4. 2013, https://www.stratfor.com/weekly/lessons-failed-attack-ethiopia
5&6 April and December 2012, https://news.vice.com/article/land-wars-ethiopia-accused-of-massacring-civilians-to-clear-way-for-foreign-farms I construct a baseline estimate of the probability of mass killing by noting that of the 48 months in 2012-2015 6 observed a mass killing (or a near miss). The probability of observing a mass killing in a given month over that time was 6/48 or 0.125.  The probability of not observing a mass killing was 1 - 0.125 = 0.875.  If I assume independence the probability of not observing a mass killing in the next 11 months before January 2017 (January 2016 has passed without a mass killing) that is 0.875^11 = 0.23.  The probability of a mass killing is then 77%. I adjust this probabilitiy downwards slightly since 2 weeks of February have passed without a mass killing as well to 74%.

Since Dec 1 2015 police have 150 people in Oromia. No international attention seems to have been brought onto this issue, suggesting that no intervention will take place. So far these protests seem to be escalating. Given this rate of killings, it seems this could easily pass the 1000 number.

According to this BBC article (1), which is corroborated by a google search, 'at least' 140 people were in the Oromia protests between November 2015 and January 8th. The use of "At least" suggests that the number is probably higher, although we're given no suggestion of how much higher. For no good reason, I think 180 is a good estimate. A more recent source (2) suggests that the dispute doesn't seem to have settled. So if we use a base rate of 90 people killed per month, we get 1080 people killed over the course of 2016, which would just about qualify as a mass killing. The pertinent question is therefore: do we expect the issue to get *worse* or *better* over 2016? I think it'll get worse for the following reasons: >Usually, when the government fires on protesters, things get worse. Off the top of my head I can think of four times when violent intervention worsened the situation (Ukraine, Tunisia, Syria, Libya), and one time when it was effective (China 1989). (Of course, 'off of the top of my head' is not a great sampling technique, so if anyone can offer some better examples, let me know). Three of those samples (Tunisia, Syria, Libya) were closely related and shouldn't be considered independent - let's call them 2 samples instead of three. It vaguely follows that 75% of the time, violent government intervention leads to a worsening situation (I will also add that in all of those samples except Tunisia, more than 1000 people were killed). I'll bump that 75% down to 50% because sampling bias - I'm more likely to remember protests that escalated into wars than those that didn't. So we'll start with a rate of 50% >Thus far, the violent intervention has not succeeded in stopping the unrest. The best predictor of future performance is past performance. If killing >140 people doesn't stop it quickly, it's probably not going to stop it slowly. Bump up 15%. >The issue underlying the unrest is deep seated and largely intractable. I imagine it is like a powder keg ready to explode: They have a distinct ethnic identity, and their economic and political marginalization will not be fixed within the year. I.e, this issue won't just "blow over" as people get bored of it. It is probably here to stay. Bump up 7%. I can't think of any obvious reasons that the situation will get better rather than worse. So I'll stick with 72% until I think about it more. (1):http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-35261314
(2):http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ca4ee89e-ce77-11e5-831d-09f7778e7377.html#axzz3zlGszQfq EDIT: I'm going to bump it down to 62% because outside view. I may do this some more later.

This is not the 80s or 90s when tens of thousands of Ethiopians were killed.  While Ethiopia is suffering from drought (which could lead to instability), most of the worst is not in areas typically wracked by violence.  In other news:
"However in a surprising move, the Oromo People's Democratic Organisation (OPDO) said on 12 January that it had resolved to "fully terminate" the plan after a three-day meeting."
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-35325536 In essence, this seems to suggest that Democracy is working. The project that was causing so much harm has been canceled and violence may subside (this project has been the source of most of the violence in the past 5 years).  http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2016/02/08/road-linking-kenya-to-ethiopia-to-be-completed-in-six-months_c1291414
In more good news, a major new road (through Oromo territory) is nearing completion. 
Roads, in Africa, bring better living conditions and the Oromo will likely benefit from this.  It is also encouraging that hundreds of thousands of jobs are being created in profitable industries for Ethiopians:
http://allafrica.com/stories/201602080571.html Nevertheless, there is also this excellent article that takes a bit more of a pessimistic view:
"The abandonment of the Master Plan is an unprecedented decision, but one that even the legal opposition considers a first step on a very long journey. It is calling for a significant gesture of appeasement, such as the freeing of the recent detainees, as proof that the government is sincerely ready to enter into dialogue with all the stakeholders concerned"
https://www.opendemocracy.net/ren-lefort/unrest-in-ethiopia-ultimate-warning-shot While there is definitely tension in and around Ethiopia (10 armed rebel groups, 2 unstable borders), Ethiopia seems to have defused the tension a little...

The most recent statistical risk assessment from the Early Warning Project puts the probability of state-led mass killing in Ethiopia at 3 percent. The wave of Oromo protests that occurred in late 2015 provides an active version of the most likely scenario for state-led mass killing in Ethiopia, so I am bumping up to 5 percent on the risk of state-led mass killing and adding 1 percent for the base-rate risk of non-state mass killing to get to 6 percent. I will trim this forecast for the passage of time without further Oromo protests and will increase it if those protests recur and the state responds with lethal violence, or if any kind of violent Oromo insurgency starts to develop (something I consider very unlikely, because I can't see any foreign patrons backing that and it would make poor strategic sense for most Oromo).

The election in 2015 saw the consolidation of power in the country and had one of the lowest levels of violence in recent electoral history.  The government is delivering strong economic growth and continues their strong police state.  They have been able to consistently disrupt rebel groups for over a decade and have a robust, mature and effective state apparatus to continue doing so. They did push hard on the Addis expansion, which was the immediate flash point for the Oromo.  However, they have backed off, so the immediate concern is likely resolved.  The various governments of ET have a long history of incorporating parts of the Oromo community (the single largest in the country) into government, or at least the benefits of government, so I predict a period of negotiations and key Oromo individuals being bought off.  This proven effective tactic also tends to take time and lower the tension levels, pushing potential flare ups some months forward. El Nino is going to bring a lot of suffering to the country, but unfortunately, the country has seen this before.  I don't recall this leading to violence.  Rather, there was violence already happening due to other issues.   The combination of carrot and stick will continue to keep the lid on a boiling pot.

You might be interested to know that we're up against experts (http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/109) on this IFP (or so it seems). I'm going to start a bit higher than the experts on this one because, well, I'm not an expert and I don't feel as comfortable being that close to the extreme. Notwithstanding @UnderwaterPutin's find (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/118483) that we're already 14% of the way there to resolving this IFP in the affirmative, the link in the more info (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-35300471) leads me to believe that there probably won't be more killing in that way. Here's the title of the link: "Ethiopia cancels Addis Ababa master plan after Oromo protests"  From the definitions page for this challenge: "We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less." So, there'd either have to be 860 more killings of Oromo people, or 1,000 killings of another specific group within Ethiopia.
